Issues.Title: Update guardian package
Issues.Body: Update the guardian package version to unblock SDL Validation - this is a subset of the failing arcade update at https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/pull/3272
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Update guardian package" (#3274)

Issues.Title: High Contrast doesn't work well by default
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: (e.g. 3.0 Preview1, or daily build number, use `dotnet --info`)
.NET 5.0 preview 6
* Windows version: (`winver`)
19041
* Does the bug reproduce also in WPF for .NET Framework 4.8?: Yes/No
Haven't tried/can't try
* Is this bug related specifically to tooling in Visual Studio (e.g. XAML Designer, Code editing, etc...)? If yes, please file the issue via the instructions [here](https://docs.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/how-to-report-a-problem-with-visual-studio?view=vs-2019).
No
* Security issues and bugs should be reported privately, learn more via our [responsible disclosure guidelines](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/blob/master/README.md#reporting-security-issues-and-security-bugs).

 <!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/blob/master/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->
 
 **Problem description:**
 Text is not visible after enabling High Contrast Mode. This is a regular WPF app using default themes/settings. It is not doing anything special for High Contrast. 

 **Actual behavior:** <!-- callstack for crashes / exceptions -->
 Text is not visible after enabling high contrast mode


 **Expected behavior:**
 Text should be visible after enabling high contrast mode
 **Minimal repro:**
Install NuGet Package Explorer from Store (or compile from GitHub at https://github.com/NuGetPackageExplorer/NuGetPackageExplorer)
1. Deploy OS.
2. Perform Store Updates.
3. Install the application from Store.
4. Launch the application.
5. Enable High contrast mode.
6. Observe.
![Screenshot_Repro](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1427284/87972814-8d6ead00-ca95-11ea-8d6d-bd9719b25d55.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "High Contrast doesn't work well by default" (#3273)

Issues.Title: Why MouseDown event doesn't work for LMB?
Issues.Body: Why MouseDown event [doesn't work](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ONQRPYDmLzhqyrIqiDbxXIO3OJopWPru/view?usp=sharing) for LMB? When I click my button via LMB nothing happens but everything works as expected for MMB and RMB.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Why MouseDown event doesn't work for LMB?" (#3271)

Issues.Title: WPF pdbs should use SourceLink
Issues.Body:
WPF commit https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/commit/847da8f
Windows 10 2004 19041.388

When debugging into WPF (PresentationFramework.pdb) the .pdb doesn't seem to have source information (SRCSRV record missing):
C:\SymbolCache\presentationframework.pdb\DC5C86C0059149FB80B01E9F5873E6AB1\presentationframework.pdb

WPF should use SourceLink so that the .pdbs are stamped with the links back to GitHub.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "WPF pdbs should use SourceLink" (#3270)

Issues.Title: WPF .NET Core no touch behavior support
Issues.Body:
I’ve used WPF Framework for years and started a .NET Core 3.1 app. My first obstacle there doesn’t appear to be any touch screen behavior support that Framework did. This seems odd considering functions like touch translate and zoom are common. VS 2019 Blend shows the behavior, but doesn’t allow it to added. When the solution is loaded back in VS the dependency for interactivity that Blend added has warning/error icon. 
Has .NET Core implemented a different class or tool to support a common function of touch translate, pan and zoom with the fluid inertia effects that Framework did?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "WPF .NET Core no touch behavior support" (#3264)

Issues.Title: CroppedBitmap does not propagate underlaying SourceBitmap changes.
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 3.1
* Windows version: 10
* Does the bug reproduce also in WPF for .NET Framework 4.8?: Don't know
* Is this bug related specifically to tooling in Visual Studio (e.g. XAML Designer, Code editing, etc...)? No

 <!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/blob/master/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->
 
 **Problem description:**

I am using an `System.Windows.Controls.Image` that has been bound to a `System.Windows.Media.Imaging.CroppedBitmap` using a `System.Windows.Media.Imaging.WriteableBitmap` as a source.

The WriteableBitmap contents are being rewritten several times per second.

If I bind the `WriteableBitmap` directly to the `Image`, the image onscreen is being updated correctly.

But if I wrap the `WriteableBitmap` with a `CroppedBitmap` and the latter is bound to the `Image`, the onscreen view is not being refreshed when I rewrite the writeable bitmap's contents.

This seems to indicate that changes on the `WriteableBitmap` are not propagated up the ladder to the `CroppedBitmap`

 
 **Actual behavior:**

The onscreen image is not updated when I rewrite the underlaying WriteableBitmap's content.
 
 **Expected behavior:**

The Image control accepts a BitmapSource as it's content source. It should play nice with **all** BitmapSource derived classes, and it should refresh the onscreen's view when the underlaying source of a CroppedBitmap is updated.

At first I thought this would be a feature request, but in truth, the inhability of CroppedBitmap to propagate changes of the underlaying BitmapSource essentially cripples CroppedBitmap for many many use cases.

Also, I consider that a CroppedBitmap wrapping another bitmap should behave exactly the same as the underlaying source bitmap, provided the cropping rectangle is of full size.  And this is not the case with WriteableBitmap when its pixels are rewritten.
 
 **Minimal repro:**

```c#
var writeable = new WriteableBitmap();
var cropped = new CroppedBitmap( writeable, new Int32Rect...);
var image = new Image();
image.Source = cropped;
// use image in a XAML for display
writeable.WritePixels(...);  // this should refresh image's onscreen view.
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "CroppedBitmap does not propagate underlaying SourceBitmap changes." (#3251)

Issues.Title: Add globbing support for WinUI
Issues.Body:
The WinUI team needs support for globbing support so that Visual Studio will not edit the .csproj whenever you add a .xaml file to the project. See this bug as a reference: https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/issues/2498

In following the same pattern as WPF, we can add a `UseWinUI` property that will pull in the `Microsoft.NET.WindowsDesktop.Sdk` and enable the globbing support.

If both `UseWinUI` and `UseWpf` are true, then the SDK can assume all xaml files are for WPF. The WinUI nuget will respect the use of `UseWpf` and not invoke the winui xaml compiler if that is the case. If only `UseWinUI` is true, then the SDK should not invoke PBT. Below is a table describing the different combinations and what should happen:

| UseWpf | UseWinUI | Xaml Compiler invoked |
|      :-:       |        :-:         |             :-:           |
|  `True`    |  `True`           | PBT                    |
|  `True`    |  `False`          | PBT                    |
|  `False`    |  `True`          | WinUI Compiler |
|  `False`    |  `False`         | neither |
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add globbing support for WinUI " (#3245)

Issues.Title: wpf `FormatLine` api cause the wpfapp-hang[serious]
Issues.Body:
<!--This is just a template - feel free to delete any and all of it and replace as appropriate.-->

### Description
AS THE ISSUE SHOW:  [WPF APP will hang if the editor SyntaxHighlighting=python](https://github.com/icsharpcode/AvalonEdit/issues/241)
